answers.answer: The EMTs are correct he needs to get it checked out since there are so many different things that might cause this - circulation problems, peripheral neuropathy for any of variety of reasons, tx-related anemia, and so on. Glad it was not serious enough to require transport.
My hepatologist told me he's stopped treatment on patients because of neuropathy. The symptoms he mentioned are numbness particularly of the feet.This man needs to talk to his liver doc asap.

Yes, I agree. Have him call the hepatologist and get this checked out right away.  There are so many different possible reasons for this symptom.  Treatment can cause blood sugar problems, so it could be related to blood sugar and circulation.  Lots of medications can cause numb or cold hands and toes, so it could be another medication not specifically related to treatment (if he's on any).  People with Hepatitis C are prone to cryoglobulinemia, which is a blood condition that can cause some changes in the skin and vascular system.  Peripheral artery disease or vascular insufficiency could cause some symptoms like this.  Peripheral nueropathy can be a side effect of treatment.  Whatever the cause is, he will need to be very careful not to burn or otherwise injure his hands or feet when they are numb as the loss of sensation can result in a serious injury and depending upon the cause of the numbness can also lead to wounds that won't heal properly.  Have him call his hepatologist tomorrow morning.Advocate1955

My husband had numbness of his left arm and hand come on suddenly a few weeks ago.  We went straight to the ER, which our doctor confirmed was the correct course of action.  We had to educate the ER doctor about sfx of INC, he knew about IFN and Riba, but no IFN.  It turned out to be nothing, and disappeared in the morning, but you don't want to mess around with this symptom.  Hoping you've spoken to his doctor by now, and if he's still experiencing, would highly recommend a trip to ER.  So much better to be safe than sorry.

I find myself sitting on my hands a lot.  A friend even gave me a little hand warmer - it is a heating pad that you can put your hands in and they warm up.  I am in week 27 -- sometimes I don't know if it is the cold or neuropathy, but I suspect neuropathy.  My first treatment I lost the feeling in my toes too but it did come back after I was done with treatment.

Thank you to those who posted.   I called our G/I yesterday and she did not think that what is happening has anything to do with the Hep C or the peg/riba treatment that my husband is on.I took him to out primary care physician who said that his blood sugar looks good, his circulation looks good, and his blood pressure looks good but thought that this is complication from diabetes.  She put him on some kind of seizure medication.But here is the deal - he will be just sitting tin a chair and he will lose all sensation in his legs and hands - so much so that he fell yesterday.  He is not in pain but is incredibly uncomfortable.I am worried.  Here is a man who 6 months ago was on no medication and other than being overweight was trundling along in life.  Now he is on pill after pill.What do you think?  Should I take him to a hepatologist?  There are a few under my health care plan - but my G/I comes well recommended as well.
I am just curious what was the seizure med for?   I find that my arms go a little numb when I am laying around.

To rule out diabetes you might consider going to an endocrinologist.  An additional medication to treat what might be doesn't sound like the best approach.  There are several with diabetes on the forum that might be able to provide their insight, but I'd want to rule that one out.  If it is diabetes, then you want to trt properly.  The HCV and the trt meds could be escalating this situation.  Just my opinion.

question: I am hoping that there is someone out that and awake.  My husband was at a buddies of his playing poker.  He does not drink.  He is on peg/riba treatment - geno 2 b with cirrhosis. This evening his hands and feet got numb.  His buddies called the ambulance who said that he was ok and did not need to be transported - although they said it needed to be checked out.He told me that this happened one time in the middle of the night.  Has this happened to anyone else?
title: numb hands and feet
